Definition: Classify the given comment whether it conveys anything impolite, offensive, or mockingly abusive by providing "insult" or "non-insult".

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Comment: Klastri, in August 2016, three days of heavy rains brought historic flooding to Louisiana.  Thirty parishes were declared disaster areas, and at least 13 people died. The Coast Guard and other first responders rescued more than 20,000 people, as the massive flooding inundated areas in and around Baton Rouge. More than 70,000 people registered for federal disaster assistance and more than 9,000 filed flood insurance claims.  With an estimated 40,000 homes damaged by deadly flooding, Louisiana was facing its biggest housing crunch since Hurricane Katrina a decade earlier.  People whose homes were swamped by some of the heaviest rains Louisiana has ever seen are staying in shelters, bunking with friends or relatives, or sleeping in trailers on their front lawns. Comment: Canaries in the coal mine? The cold water upwellings that bring the deep water nutrients closer to the surface where the krill feed on them which in turn support these birds and our fisheries could be breaking down from the warmer waters in the North Pacific. Think of it as a conveyor belt moving cold nutrient rich water to the surface where it can be utilized by the small crustaceans and copepods that herring and these birds feed on. What people don't realize is this system is the foundation of the entire food chain in this ecosystem. It breaks down and everything that depends on it, including us suffer. I can't believe some of the stupid and ignorant comments on here and I dearly pray they do no reflect  people's intellect and politics. How depressing.

Comment: I think you overestimate Earth's carrying capacity for industrialized nations and their populations. 140 million birth/year - 58 million deaths per year (pre-Trump figure) = 82 million more mouths to feed every year! 10 billion is the agreed-upon limit for being to feed a global population, assuming we feed everyone now, which we do not! As we approach 7.5 billion by year's end, 2016, it would perhaps be appropriate to pause and reflect on this. We are 2.5 billion away from reaching  total carrying capacity: 2.5 billion/82 million per year = 87 years (IF rates remain constant, which they do not - so, more like 30 years, TOPS!).  AND WE ALREADY CAN'T FEED EVERYONE.

As for being "bold enough to be their superstore", these industrial groceries aren't very healthy and certainly not sustainable. Are we to be so bold as to attempt to feed garbage food to billions of people? That doesn't sound bold, it sounds like a fool's gambit.

Comment: Mike, think for a moment about the arrogant idiocy of your comment.  Do you recall the impact of the July 2013 storm which flooded the subway, countless basements, and resulted in   massive insurance claims.  That was for 100mm to 125mm of rain over the GTA.  The 5 feet of rain in Houston is about 1700mm, or 15x that much.  Use you imagination and think what that would mean.  In a city full of valleys and ravines, the flooding would be unimaginable.  Houston's biggest asset and liability is that it is flat.  Flat means drainage is tough, but also that the water is not moving much.  So while the water is 4 ft deep, it is 4ft deep just about everywhere, and it is relatively calm.  In Toronto, the high ground would be fine, but the ravines would be roaring rivers of destruction.  I would bet the death toll from 5 feet of water in Toronto would be way higher than in Houston.

Comment: I think states are stupid to enact their own term limits under the current system....but I'm all for term limits becoming a nationwide policy.

If it were left to me, a Senate term would be 8 years, 6 for president, and 4 for the House.  Someone can serve one of each, and then they're out.  This way they spend the bulk of their time doing their job, not running for office.  I would also require someone to resign their current position once they declare their candidacy.  In other words, you're either a Senator or a presidential candidate....not both.  That way, we don't get 16 candidates from one party.

Comment: I recall this R-G letter of 2006, "Reduce nighttime light pollution"
  
This letter is a request for people to evaluate their nighttime residential lighting and try to determine if it falls into the category of light pollution. 

Light pollution is misused or misdirected light, such as sky glow, glare and light trespass. Sky glow is light causing a glow over urban areas. Glare is light shining menacingly into people's eyes as they walk or dirve by. Light trespass is unwanted light shining onto a heighbor's property or into their house.

My family has experienced vandalism and theft, but high wattage, polluting lights around my house would not have prevented it, as it occureed in broad daylight.

Comment: Here is my guess and I will be the first to say that, like all of us here, we are assuming a lot. 

People seem to think there is an easy black market for weapons and I just don't think that's the case. I see a constant argument that criminals are just buying the guns illegally, and gun restrictions won't keep guns out of the hands of criminals. And while that may be the case in small pockets I disagree. 

To me, I think there are 4 easier explanations. 

1 A seemingly normal, law-abiding citizen buys a gun and then, seemingly unpredictably uses it in a crime. 

2 A person buys guns legally, commits a crime in which they would be prohibited from possessing a gun, keeps the gun through a number of different oversights and then uses the gun in a future crime. 

3 A person who is prohibited from possessing a gun takes or is given a gun be an acquaintance who, otherwise, is a normal gun owner.

4 A person who should be prohibited from possessing a gun is able to buy one due to oversights.

Comment: Programming languages are a teaching tool that lets you objectively demonstrate critical thinking. You can illustrate -- plain as day! -- how logic works, how the assumptions one makes when forming an opinion affects the result of that opinion, how to break down a question into its constituent parts, etc.. You are basically telling a computer how to "think" about something.

That said, you have to be teaching the right things. If the goal is "make a web page and learn HTML" then I agree, that is of limited use. If the goal is "learn how to work with variables, functions and flow control in Python, then -- if we have time -- hook the inputs and outputs up to a web app" then that is teaching a broad range of logic skills, with minimal technical involvement (Python's syntax is very easy to understand).

Comment: The 14th Amendment was written to to protect the rights of American born freed slaves. It was written so states couldn't deny them citizenship. In my opinion SCOTUS has interpreted the Amendment poorly. One of the authors of the Amendment, Senator Jacob Howard, I think would agree with me as he wrote, ""Every person born within the limits of the United States, and subject to their jurisdiction, is by virtue of natural law and national law a citizen of the United States. This will not, of course, include persons born in the United States who are foreigners, aliens, who belong to the families of ambassadors or foreign ministers accredited to the Government of the United States, but will include every other class of persons. It settles the great question of citizenship and removes all doubt as to what persons are or are not citizens of the United States. This has long been a great desideratum in the jurisprudence and legislation of this country."

Comment: Dear reader, this author's rosy presentation of Canadian history is very self-serving and ignores the ugly parts of Canadian history that resulted from the heavy-handed expansion practices that were almost entirely a centrist enterprise.

Left out is the fed's ordeal with the Metis in the west which ultimately led to the bloodiest rebellion in Canadian history (1885).

The Indian Act, yes, that instrument of the fed's blundersome treatment of First Nations, was another entirely-federal enterprise.

The Canadian Pacific Railway and other enterprises subsidized by the fed disadvantaged western farmers, the end result of which was the formation of radical parties like the CCF, which ultimately led to the formation of social welfare programs like publicly funded medicare and other socialist policies.

I can go on, but I implore you, study Canada's post-confederation history and you'll find it's less rosy than this author suggests.

Comment: One fine Thursday in January, 2016, right around when the miracle of Obamacare was really hitting its stride, I ended up in the emergency room at Providence for a kidney stone.I don't think I've ever experienced so much pain before in my life I had to run to the restroom three separate times to get sick.I was checked in around 6pm. At 12:30 am, Friday morning, six and a half hours later, I was admitted for treatment.The emergency room was packed. I counted upwards of 130 people waiting for treatment. There was a constant stream of new people.  Later, at 3:30am, when I slowly made my way to my car, there were still 30 people waiting for treatment.

Once in my room, after the nurses saw the state I was in, they were very apologetic for the wait. One even suggested calling an ambulance next time - I'd probably be admitted sooner.  They also told me it was like that most nights. I asked wasn't Obamacare supposed to cut down on use of the emergency room? The nurses just shrugged.

Comment: Okay, a real story about United that happened to my wife and I just last week.  We had to get emergency tickets to O'Hare on United.  The plane was at the gate for about an hour after the departure time. The pilot said the delay was due to a belligerent  passenger in first class that had to be booted.  Okay, that sort of thing happens.  We push back from the gate and taxi around for a time.  We then approach the gate again.  This time we are told the plane was low on fuel.  We load up and go back to taxi for a long period of time.  We go back to the gate only to be told that now we are overweight.  Two passengers were announced over the intercom to leave the plane.  Finally we push back and are on our way.  We landed at LAX massively missing our connection and are told to wait with everyone else who missed their flights.  Finally we are rebooked to O'Hare only to wait for another seven hours for that flight.  United never once apologized.  Never again will I fly this airline.

Comment: "Nearly 190 million people tuned in for the inaugural season for Formula E,"

More people will have watched 2017 Lemans 24, which ran yesterday and Saturday, than all those who watched the entire 2016 Formula E season. F1 draws 700M - 800M viewers annually. Formula E is a spec series with a common chassis (Dallara) and a FIA mandated limit on HP (270) and speed (225Kph). Its hardly the future. I saw part of the Formula E race is Miami in March 2015, and while it was interesting to watch, It was no better than GP3 and no where near F1. Formula E will live or die based on the quality of the racing - not that it's electric.

Comment: Driving on Oahu is akin to torture.  There are obvious reasons that red light runners seem routine: 1) Yellow lights are extremely long here making it possible to make it through an intersection on the yellow from longer starting points than on the mainland; 2) Everyone knows there is a long period after the light turns red before opposing traffic gets a green light (also longer than most mainland locations); 3) Traffic light timing is abysmal, causing drivers to have extra motivation to try not to get stuck at a red light.  If Honolulu got its game together on traffic management first, then it might seem reasonable to go after red light runners.  As it is, putting up red light cameras now is further penalizing people who are already prisoners of a failed system.

Comment: Healthcare is NOT necessary for survival.
Cosmetic surgery, birth control, sex changes, common cold treatment (in emergency rooms), and a host of other things that fall under the broad umbrella of "healthcare" aren't necessary at all.  SOME healthcare is necessary.  Life-saving healthcare is necessary.
Need does not give anyone a right.  Just because you "need" healthcare doesn't mean you have a "right" to it - because it is a service that someone else provides and does so to be compensated.  No one has a right that obligates anyone else.  That's not about greed, race or any of the other foolish things leftists tell themselves while suffering from Hodgkinson's disease.  If one service is a "right" than ALL services are rights.  If "need" grants a right to healthcare, than it grants a right to luxury homes, cars, and yachts.

Comment: This is info from another poster w/the name "s e":
The national popular vote is the total of the vote in all 50 states and DC.
Federal law (Title 3, chapter 1, section 6 of the U.S. Code) requires the states to report the November popular vote numbers in what is called a "Certificate of Ascertainment." They are posted on the NARA web site.
There is nothing in Article II (or elsewhere in the Constitution) that prevents states from making the decision now that winning the national popular vote is required to win the presidency.
The U.S. Supreme Court has repeatedly characterized the authority of the state legislatures over the manner of awarding their electoral votes as "plenary" and "exclusive."
Article I-Section 10, Clause 3 of the U.S. Constitution specifically permits states to enter interstate compacts. In fact, there are hundreds of major compacts currently in force (and thousands of minor ones).

Summary:
The National Popular Vote is required by law.

Comment: I used to live in a red light camera state.  The tickets are $400.  The majority of this goes to the company operating the camera system, just like this article states 70% of the fine goes to the company.  This profit margin resulted in many tickets being thrown out when it was discovered that the company set the cameras to go off early.  This third-party camera company receives their fee for every ticket, whether or not the local cop decides to prosecute it or prosecutes and loses.  The result of the $400 fine is that in these particular intersections that have lights, people slow down and are more wary of crossing, making it take much longer for people to get across the intersections.  It has no impact on any other intersection in town.  Anchorage won't become safer, just a couple intersections will.  We'll pay more for APD to review the pictures, the courts to process tickets, and camera fees than we'll receive in benefit.  That's why they've been pulled in other cities.

Comment: Honestly, I think this really boils down to the evolution of Boy Scouting into a family-based activity.  I married an Eagle Scout who went on to become an Assistant Scoutmaster long before we had children of our own. I soon joined in the fun as a Scouter, and when we became parents, our children of both genders wanted in on the action. It was painful for our daughter to be excluded, and the wait for Venture Scouting, which became available to her at age 13, felt like an eternity. We wanted very much to experience Scouting as a family, not as separate genders, and that appears to be true of many of our generational peers. Both organizations would be wise to think long and hard about how they can remain relevant, and if that means looking beyond single-gender programs, so be it. Our family would cheer the progress!

Comment: DB plans were created when generally employee's started around 20 years of age, worked for 45 years and then conveniently passed away about 5 years later. Now people are starting later in life, work less number of years and in many cases live until their mid eighties or better.  Numbers don't work out now and the investment returns have been less predictable.

Comment: The National Popular Vote bill would replace state winner-take-all laws that award all of a state’s electoral votes to the candidate who get the most popular votes in each separate state (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), in the enacting states, to a system guaranteeing the majority of Electoral College votes for, and the Presidency to, the candidate getting the most popular votes in the entire United States. 
		
The bill retains the constitutionally mandated Electoral College and state control of elections, and uses the built-in method that the Constitution provides for states to make changes. It ensures that every voter is equal, every voter will matter, in every state, in every presidential election, and the candidate with the most votes wins, as in virtually every other election in the country.

Comment: Consider this idea. When we drive on the road today, the paint on the road is fixed. 

But what if it wasn't ? What if the road is a blank slate.

Imagine, there are 3 regular car lanes, but during rush hour, the paint markings are digitally altered. Either this is a digital display in the car, or it's a virtualized road lighting.

One regular car lane remains, and the other 2 lanes are split in half and become 4 lanes, which only little cars can drive on. So the 3 lanes are now 5 lanes - same road - only a change in the display.

The capacity has increased width wise. Also, since the car has smaller length, the capacity has also increased length wise. This change can easily double road capacity on all GTA roads.

Fundamentally, in the same volume of space, we are fitting more vehicles.

Comment: You are equating the 500,000 tank cars to a propane truck refueling a neighbor's tank as an argument to dismiss the regulation of these trains? How are they comparable?
1. What number of propane trucks refuel a neighbor's tank? Actually none, as they do so indirectly. No one hooks up a tank to a propane truck. The trucks deliver it to a storage facility.
2. Each propane truck has one driver. A train may have a few crew for a hundred cars.
3. How often do propane trucks blow up compared to oil trains?
4. When oil tank cars derail and explode, many do so as they each catch fire. Is this the same level of threat as a propane truck?

Your argument appears to be a fallacy of false equivalence. There are some similarities, but not enough to apply the one of risk to both oil trains and propane trucks.

Comment: He was objecting to the P.C. notion that the term "Master" was related to slavery. It isn't, any more than the term "history" means "HIS story", as the more extreme feminists a few decades ago claimed. The attempt to replace "history" with "herstory" has thankfully failed, it was bad etymology, just as this is.

The notion of being a Master comes from a time when young people learned their craft as apprentices, or students, of experts, i.e. master craftsmen or school masters. In a very hierarchical society, adults in charge of educating, guiding, ordering people around, whether children or apprentices or servants, were called "masters". 

Today the term Maître is still used as a title for lawyers and notaries in French speaking countries.

Comment: Indigenous whalers in Alaska voluntarily abides by the rules of the International Whaling Commission: "Enforcement under the IWC. IWC is a voluntary international organization and is not backed up by treaty. Therefore, the IWC, in essence, is a voluntary organization which has substantial practical limitations on its authority. First, any member countries are free to simply leave the organization and declare themselves not bound by it if they so wish. Second, any member state may opt out of any specific IWC regulation by lodging a formal objection to it within 90 days of the regulation coming into force[24] (such provisions are common in international agreements, on the logic that it is preferable to have parties remain within the agreements than opt out altogether). Third, the IWC has no ability to enforce any of its decisions through penalty imposition."

"A picture of the world population in the very long-run shows extremely rapid growth. Indeed, for a long time the world population grew at an increasing rate. However, if we focus on the last couple of decades, we see that this pattern no longer holds, as the annual rate of population growth has been recently going down. 1962 saw the growth rate peak at 2.1%, and it has since fallen to almost half. A long historical period of accelerated growth has thus come to an end."  (https://ourworldindata.org/world-population-growth/)
While poor areas in Africa and the Middle East still have problems,  in much of the West birth rates are falling below death rates.
The real problem now is technology.

Comment: It was a function of a few things.

A lot of the folks that played there were appealing to an audience that is old and getting older.  If i had to guess, I'd guess that that translated into diminishing ticket sales.

I live about 10 blocks from Hugh's and while i didn't go very often (sadly, these days that's true of all live music) I've noticed that the bigger names that used to feature frequently in their lineup seem to have tailed off.  That could easily be due to a lot of the older acts simply not being able to tour in Canada or choosing not to, or a symptom of bad times for that club, or bad times for live music pitched primarily at an increasingly old audience.

I've never heard anyone have much good to say about their food.  I can't speak to it myself, but the absence of good comments speaks loudly.

The business of music generally is not an easy one, and so far as I know that venue never made money and was financed by the owner from day one.  Sad but (I believe) true.

RIP.

Aloha --  Dennis

Comment: Heidi, I wish you luck in the quest  to revitalize the Newport Hills Shopping Center. In Lake Hills I seem to recall several meetings, most well attended, in which the City sought input into what the community wanted. I'd have to rummage through my notes - this is getting to be quite a while ago  - yet I seem to recall a great deal of interest in refurbishing the grocery store, at the time a QFC. Not wanting to engage in a long process, QFC instead moved to a rebuilt Bel-East Shopping Center in roughly the same neighborhood. My understanding is that Mr. Del Moro (the developer) still seeks a grocery store.

Lake Hills had traffic concurrency controversies, relatively little interest in including housing (at least at the meetings), concerns with size and scale, and a bunch of other stuff you're undoubtedly familiar with. Is Lake Hills Shopping Center "successful?" Since it's finish, I hope it won't be a white elephant in the long-term. It doesn't offer anything I find of interest now.

Comment: Sadly, carbon monoxide poisoning is an insidious threat which has killed many pilots in the past.  Just as one should always have carbon monoxide detectors anywhere there is a combustion heater, I always recommend that anyone flying a small plane carry and use one of the various types of small, portable electronic detector/alarms which are readily available.  Unlike the cheap, slow responding and hard-to-see chemical disks folks often buy and stick on the dashboard as an afterthought, the electronic monitors have quick response times, loud alarms, and flashing lights.  I carry a small "Pocket CO" on my keychain.  To me, the $140 or so that I paid for it is well worth the investment in the safety of myself and my passengers, and the peace of mind that it brings while flying is priceless.

Deepest condolences to the pilot and family.  If anything could be gained from this, at least let it be a greater awareness of this threat which might save the lives of others in the future.

Comment: I was a paramedic for 14 years in Toronto and I've seen several drivers do this.  Each time I stopped, got out of my car and told the person not to follow me.  If they got into an accident following me then I'd have to stop and help them, and the person I was responding to would have a delayed response.  I always felt that we should have a camera facing backward that the second paramedic could monitor and if someone was 'drafting' us we could just send the video of it to the cops and they'd send the dangerous driver a massive ticket.

I do have to say though, that MOST people, MOST of the time, are thoughtful and let us through.  We notice that, and we thank you.  It's a privilege to be able to help.

Also, for the record, EMT is a (mostly) American term.  In Canada we are all called paramedics.

Comment: Under Canadian law today, I believe a good many men and women have committed sexual assault, usually of a minor degree of course.. (I don't say that to normalize it, but to make people aware of their own actions and words.)

Here's my understanding. If, out of a sexual motive, you apply (or threaten to apply) physical force of any sort to someone without their consent, you are liable to a charge of sexual assault. For example, a patron in a bar might be sexually attracted to someone they don't know, and grab his/her bum on the dance floor. That's sexual assault, although the typical consequence is to be ejected from the bar rather than charges being laid. So yes, I believe that it is routine for people to speak of committing sexual assault, although they would probably deny that what they did or were contemplating was an offence.

As for more serious forms of sexual assault, no- I've never heard someone talk of committing it.

The world around us doesn't seem to make a lot of sense some days but going to church puts my mind at ease and I relish the quiet hour of peace and oneness I so often feel.  Thank you, Kelly, for telling your story and warming my heart on this Easter Sunday.... as I run from child to child who've only been able to visit the porcelain god today due to the blessing of a stomach virus.  I was missing going to church today but your article transported me there, if only for a few minutes between dashes to the kids.

Comment: The problem is Wind and Solar are not reducing C02 and our government will not admit this costly failure. Ontario’s professional Engineers, those tasked with generation, transmission and billing, have reported the problem. our government continues to build more wind and solar.

Reference: “Ontario’s Electricity Dilemma – Achieving Low Emissions at Reasonable Electricity Rates”. Ontario Society of Professional Engineers (OSPE). April 2015.
(Archived at: http://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.ospe.on.ca/resource/resmgr/DOC_advocacy/2015_Presentation_Elec_Dilem.pdf)

Page 15 of 23. “Why Will Emissions Double as We Add Wind and Solar Plants ?”

– Wind and Solar require flexible backup generation.

– Nuclear is too inflexible to backup renewables without expensive engineering changes to the reactors.

– Flexible electric storage is too expensive at the moment.  Consequently natural gas provides the backup for wind and solar in North America.

Comment: One answer is density and good transit. As an example Paris' density is about 4 times that of Vancouver, there are probably no single family homes, and for the same land area it has about 250 subways stations.  Plus many bus lines. So within the city the system works very well. But commuting into Paris is still difficult, roads, freeways and commuter lines are packed. 
Here in Vancouver we live 10 minutes from downtown, transit is excellent as long as one is not too far from the center. We rarely drive and fill up four times a year. High density makes it possible to have efficient transit.
The post war expansion of the suburbs has been a disaster in terms of mobility, pollution and wasteful use of land, but the development industry would carry on building on farmland farther and farther out if it was allowed.

Comment: The key to the economic health we have enjoyed the last few decades has been economic diversification.  Back in the 1980s the economy was dominated by the energy sector and we were handed our heads.  Since then we have evolved several times with first the cable sector then the tech boom and the revitalization of Downtown and the addition of our light rail system with the development that brings along the routes.  Having Amazon move here would be a catalyst for what is already a growing technology sector and will strengthen our economy for at least the next couple of decades.  Some rave about manufacturing jobs but what people don't seem to see is that the jobs that companies like Amazon bring have the multiplier effects that manufacturing once had.  The great thing is that we don't have to do much to attract the Amazons and Googles since the people who work for them want to live in a place like Colorado.

Comment: Built in fans in the Kitchen and bathrooms, and portable fans in windows, can cool off your house faster when the temperature outside drops in the evening, but don't leave the windows open when you are out.

If you have a limited number of fans try to position them in pairs, with one blowing cool air in and another blowing air out after travelling through the house. Consider which side of your house is shaded in the afternoon as the best cool air source, but if there is a strong breeze or wind you may be better off working with the natural flow of air than trying to work against it.

Open doors along the travel path of the air.

http://www.wikihow.com/Use-Window-Fans-for-Home-Cooling

https://www.overstock.com/guides/tips-on-cooling-your-home-with-window-fans

If you only have one fan you may want to focus the cooling on a bedroom, leave the window there open and put the fan away from it.

http://www.instructables.com/id/Cool-Your-House-With-Negative-Pressure-Ventilation/

Comment: This trend actually goes back a few years. My 2001 BMW 330 Ci has a dipstick but also a sensor to tell me if the oil level is too low. It is on the bottom of the oil pan and I replaced it once myself and I still do oil changes - and well before the 25,000k's BMW says was needed.
Fast forward to the 2011 328i my wife just got and there is no dipstick. There is however a maintenance screen that will tell you the oil level if you find it in the idrive system and once you find it no problem.
The mechanic Bill on Motoring did a segment on these new systems last year so they are becoming more common.
Unfortunately - I think most of us who read these columns and respond to them are "old" school and we do not represent the vast majority of car owners or lessees's these days who wouldn't even know how to open the hood.
I taught both my kids the basics but if they will ever need them in the future , who knows.

Comment: There's a problem here with leadership. It's reactive rather than pre-emptive.

There's a story I love from Formula 1 racing. It goes back to 1997 where the Williams team won the championship in the controversial last race of the year. Amongst the controversies was what amounted to wire tapping by the Ferrari team - a practice that had long been suspected but which was now confirmed.

It was put to one of the Williams engineers that they might have done the same if the boot were on the other foot. He said no, Sir Frank Williams calls the team management in at the start of every season and tells them what his team will not do. It doesn't matter if others do it and prosper, the Williams team does not do these things.

That's leadership. 

Too often these days - in business and in politics - leadership is reactive. They don't draw a pre-emptive line, they react when something happens and try to talk their way out of it.

Comment: It would be smarter to start figuring out an alternative economic model to the "constant demographic growth" one. We need to figure out how to manage population stabilisation or even decline, that would be better long-term planning.

And Canada's success so far at integrating immigrants is due to the facts that 1) we had enforceable borders that allowed us to select them wisely, 2) in "digestible" numbers, 3) that they came from a variety of cultural sources in successive waves, not a huge mass from a single one, 4) that they settled all over the country, and 5) that they were eager to integrate. Mass immigration from single cultural sources, that settle in a handful of large urban centers, which is happening now, is a recipe for disaster.

Comment: Arguably, polling firms were correct in 2013 in gauging (a) matters as they stood a week before the campaign ended, & (b) Party support at that earlier time.  The conventional wisdom was that voter preferences don't shift much within the campaign's last week.

However, there was a late shift in 2013 and its consequence was greatly amplified when many younger voters (i.e. most likely to vote NDP) didn't turn out.

This year, the polling firms are sampling up to the campaign's end and sharpening their techniques.  Their different reported results arguably reflect whether the questions asked measure general preference (which nets higher NDP support) or stronger intention (which nets closer results).

Firms this year are also stressing preference differences by voting age.

Conclusion, the 2017 polling snapshots are accurate (but each firm measures slightly different things) and these snapshots all imply that whether young voters turn out (or not) will decide who wins.

Comment: Marty, in all intellectual discussion, the preexisting perspective (my preferred term for your "basic premises") of the parties clearly determine each sides thrust in the discussion. On that we agree.

However, I further postulate that in many apparently futile arguments each side regularly assumes its knows (1) the other side's premises and (2) that those premises are false; but that mutual assumption is also regularly false. 

There is a test. If Side A truly understands Side B's perspective, then Side A can produce Side B's position with such accuracy that Side B recognizes it as their own. In fact, Side A almost invariably produces a caricature that Side B rejects, but Side A insists is absolutely true. And the same in reverse happens when Side B attempts to produce Side A's position. 

When that happens, a dispassionate third party would fairly conclude that the two parties do not in fact understand each other. 

IMHO, discussion with a view to passing the test is useful.

Comment: There is absolutely nothing wrong with the Grass Creek development.  I live about a mile away (near Cheney Lake), and walk my dogs through Begich Middle and through/around Grass Creek on a very regular basis.  I have long been impressed by the pride of ownership evident in the nicely landscaped and sparkling clean development, and the community center where there are always kids gathered to play.  This spills over into Begich as well, and I'm consistently amazed by the number of community kids running on the track or playing basketball on evenings and weekends, just enjoying the outdoors and doing their thing.  Having lived in the lower 48 I thought I could spot Section 8 housing from a mile away, but I was surprised when I learned GC is a low/mixed income development.  Honestly, the place looks more well kept than many of the single family homes (300 - 500k) in our subdivision, where we've got  "middle class" folks with blue tarps and junked cars on their lawns.

Comment: There are a lot of things that could be funded with the $3.3 trillion in annual federal revenues. In 2016, the federal government decided to fund $3.9 trillion worth of things resulting in a $585 billion deficit.
-
HTJ stated "...we choose increasingly not to budget properly for that, and waste the money on things, like walls, space exploration, and the military." Those three things are a small %.
-
The key phrase being "...choose...to...not to budget properly..." The choice has been made to budget 67% ($2.6 trillion) on entitlement programs leaving little else for any other national  priorities.
-
HTJ is stating the criticism that budgeting is not being done properly. I replied as to what the budgeting choices were, where current funding is being applied. HTJ pointing to walls, space and defense obviously fails to acknowledge that federal entitlement programs consume the vast majority of federal spending. Highlighting walls, space and defense while ignoring entitlements is fallacious.

Comment: How could I possibly ignore it?  It's brought us to the brink of financial collapse.

"A democracy is always temporary in nature; it simply can't exist as a permanent form of government. Comment: May it be the U.S.A or Canada, the fact remains that a great number of the population goes undiagnosed with this condition. 
Is just that simple. 
Yes indeed it does happen here in Canada as well, more times than we like to admit it. 
I speak from personal experience, having to have gone undiagnosed with Graves' disease for many years. All the wonderful tests were taken, feeling like a porcupine after having all those needles stuck in me, exposed to all sorts of gamma rays but all in good faith and good reason. 
Finally, after 2 (two) years, three specialists and four hospitals I had a concrete diagnosis....Graves disease. All my symptoms were rather opposite to what the "norm" is for this particular illness, hence the diagnosis was harder to pinpoint, even with blood tests, x-rays, scans and you name it.
Please have yourself checked and do not give up if it does not feel right, why put yourself and your loved  through so much agony when there is no need for it.   
Best of luck.

But looking at the [stupid and gratuitously rude] canned points you endlessly make, here and in every fluoridation discussion in the English-speaking world, got me thinking, and looking, and paying attention.

To my mind, the very strongest argument against the "necessity" for fluoridated water is the fact that the countries whose governments provide their citizens' healthcare (which is most of the developed world) have also decided to stop fluoridating their water.  

If the guy who writes the checks that pay for the dental care of every kid in the country decides those kids don't need fluoride in their water, that's called "putting your money where your mouth is"  --  very literally.

Comment: Historically, immigration to the United States has been cyclical. In times of labor shortages, large numbers of immigrants are admitted to fill them. When the labor shortage ends and  unemployment is high, immigration has to be reduced. Right now, unemployment and especially under-employment are at near-crisis levels.

It is also inaccurate to compare today's immigrants with those of previous generations. When Nussbaum's grandfather-in-law came, there was no public housing, no food stamps, no affirmative action, no Medicare; immigrants came and made their way without demanding support from the taxpayers. There was no Facebook, no dual passports, no cell phones, no "global citizens"; immigrants left their country and connections behind and strove to become loyal Americans.

Comment: The parable of the widow’s mite (Luke 21:1-4) is that the poor widow who gave only a small amount to the treasury gave more than the rich who gave out of their abundance fits well with the economic theory of the declining marginal utility of money.  

The more money a person has, the less a new dollar of wealth adds to their wellbeing.  

By transferring resources from the wealthy to the less wealthy, the resources are placed with those who value them more.

The parable of the good Samaritan told of two men who knew that they should have helped another who had been robbed and wounded but did not, and a third man, who did not have an obligation, but did (Luke 10: 30-36).  

A progressive tax may force wealthy free-loaders who believe that aiding the poor is not their social responsibility to meet, the obligation that they wish to avoid.  

Add it all up and one could build a case for public policy to take that into consideration.

A true Christian couldn't object.

Her gift to me was her example of how how she tolerated my foibles (and those of my siblings), how she stayed in a marriage when today people might not.... and above all her courageous battle with cancer. Those influences may have been beyond my control, but they were choices she made and at considerable sacrifice, to give me the best possible future . Yes, society should allow me to reap that advantage. Families are entitled to cultivate advantage in their children. 
PS - Yes, they took me to the ROM. It was BORING !!!! I took my sons to WWF and Monster Truck competitions and Green Day concerts - I hope that served them even bette'

Comment: Personally, I think a step backwards.  Football is inherently physical and often violent.  One of the reasons it appeals to us, although many will deny. Don't even mention boxing or ultimate fighting.

Comment: The objective of a hate crime is to target not just the immediate victim, but also others of the same race, religion, sexuality, etc. In other words, if Corporon's father and nephew, as well as the other victims, were killed specifically because they were Christians, it absolutely was a hate crime and needed to be prosecuted as such. Was the perpetrator's objective simply a mass killing (something already far too common in our society), or was there an additional motive of terrorizing Christians? Since he reportedly intended to kill Jews, there's already good evidence that he was targeting a specific group, so the implication is there.

Hate crimes can be pretty hard to pin down, but they should be investigated where evidence exists because often there is an underlying wish to inspire others to engage in the same sort of actions. What perpetrators want is the targeted group to live in fear. No one should fear for their lives because of their race, religion, sexuality, etc.

Comment: Holiness has been long ago defined.

In fact, the pagan Aristotle got quite close to it with his definition of happiness, which is totally unknown to today's crowd, including sadly most Catholics. 

A "whole life well lived" (virtuous, moral) was Aristotle's definition of happiness. 

Aquinas took that long view - a life long view of never quite getting there until death - and elevated it.

Holiness is living in unity with God's will, totally corresponding to His will for the sake of His glory (not for our sake).  Holiness has the Other, Himself, built into it, unlike Aristotle.    

Aquinas showed that all human virtues (the matter of the Greeks) at their vanishing point..or their point of perfection touch on the good of God. 

And so happiness (properly understood in terms of this deeper Greek meaning) and Holiness are highly related. 

Holiness is partaking in the divine life of the Trinity, our thoughts and desires become what He planned for us.

Inclined plane, a lifetime's work.

Comment: A reader of the Scriptures of course should be open to many suggestions with regard to how to interpret a particular passage. But that reader should also understand that Johannine literature is tricky; the theology is peculiar (the only sustained "high christology" in the NT), and so is the vocabulary that supports it.

"Truth," as in John 18.37, as quoted in the article, followed by Pilate's "What is truth?" in the next verse, and even more clearly in "And you will know the truth, and the truth will make you free," 8.32, refers to the Johannine community's particular insight regarding Jesus (and not at first shared by other Christian communities of the first century), that he is the Word of God who was with God in the beginning and is come into the world.

If a reader wishes to apply these verses to other, more generally accepted meanings of "truth," he/she is free to do so, but is advised to proceed with caution.

Comment: Folks, please consider learning a bit more about the law before making these kinds of disparaging comments about judges, prosecutors, and the relative time that one defendant gets compared to others.  Facts matter.  The law matters.

Adams wasn't being sentenced for intentional murder, but a lesser charge of criminally negligent homicide.  This limits the number of years a judge can sentence him to.  And part of the reason the judge had his hands tied is that the DA decides what charges to bring.  Those charges were less than the DA wanted, too, because the defendant's statements to police were thrown out - meaning that the DA didn't have a strong enough case to bring higher charges.

You could try to blame the police for whatever conduct got the interrogation suppressed, but they work hard every day, too, and want to put away criminals just as much as you do.  Ultimately, judges, prosecutors, and others have do their best with the facts they're given.  They have to follow the law too.

Comment: The point, Byegolly,  is NOT that "many people do not feel the system is broken." Or even that they might feel it is. 

The Swiss have a system of social aid.  Nobody accused it of being "broken," yet the Swiss government took the question of basic income to the people anyway in one of 13 referendums held in that country last year.  Nobody could accuse the government of "working for itself" or "in its own best interests", nobody could blame anybody when they all had an opportunity to vote on the subject.  

There are two points: people having expressing their personal feelings on the issue.  The second point (sadly): the PM abandoned an important election promise.  Happily, we'll all get to express our feelings about THAT issue in less than 3 years.

Comment: It is not just the elimination of the presumption of innocence that flows from "believe the victim".  It also raises a presumption that there is, in fact, a "victim".  Absent a conviction then, consistent with the fact that an accused is presumed innocent, is the fact that it has not been proven that there is a victim at all.  Furthermore, in cases where the sex was consensual or where it didn't even take place, the only victim is the person who has been falsely accused and whose accuser, unlike the accused, is entitled to remain nameless throughout and suffers no legal expense.  What those who advocate for "believe the victim" are really advocating for is "believe the accuser".

Comment: "I don’t understand why it’s so difficult to pass a transportation bill in the legislature" -- Lori McLemore

Easy, Ms. McLemore. Some legislators felt their opposition to even proposing a tax increase to voters outweighed voters being given a chance to decide for themselves.
These legislators wrapped themselves in the magic bulletproof mantle of "defenders of TABOR". But these legislators conveniently forget -- blatantly ignore -- that TABOR expressly authorizes the legislature to ask voters permission for a tax increase.
These are the same legislators who would oppose a "fee increase" on the grounds it would be an end-run on TABOR. But, when given a chance to follow TABOR by asking voters for a tax increase, they say "no".
To heck with traffic congestion, crumbling roads and bridges. No taxes then, no taxes now, no taxes forever is their mantra.

Comment: Ross:  Yes, scraped, sold, burned and I've heard of some that were buried. A good number were converted to power and had a second life as "conversions." Boats I know of that are on exhibit:  State Museum in Juneau; Pratt Museum in Homer; Museum of Transportation off the Parks Highway which also has a conversion; Lake Clark National Park in Port Alsworth; Columbia River Maritime Museum in Astoria,OR; APA Museum in Blaine, WA which is also restoring / rebuilding one to sail.  Wooden Boat Center on Lake Union in Seattle has one that sails around the lake.  City of Dillingham has one that is displayed each summer at the local cannery.  Anchorage Museum had one that it unfortunately took off display, but sent this summer to the Bristol Bay Historical Society in Naknek for display. There are some in private ownership that are still floating / sailing including the one in Homer pictured in the article.

Support for a National Popular Vote

Comment: Before Mr Trudeau's half-digested Senate reforms we had an appointed if largely powerless Senate that was, through party discipline, under control of the elected Commons. We need to keep a close watch and get rid of elected officials as necessary through the ballot box. We no longer have that ability when it comes to the upper chamber.  The gov't thought it had found the key to senate reform by appointing only saints. The government, as the article points out, has done a foolish, dangerous thing. Comment: The Julian calendar, used from 1677 AD on for fiscal matters only, was adopted on March 13, 1840 AD (March 1, 1256 AH), in the frame of Tanzimat reforms shortly after the accession to the throne of Sultan Abdülmecid I, as the official calendar for all civic matters and named "Rumi calendar" (literally Roman calendar).[1] The counting of years began with the year 622 AD, when Muhammad and his followers emigrated from Mecca to Medina, the same event marking the start of the Islamic calendar. The months and days of the Julian calendar were used, the year starting in March.[2] However, in 1256 AH the difference between the Hijri and the Gregorian calendars amounted to 584 years. With the change from lunar calendar to solar calendar, the difference between the Rumi calendar and the Julian or Gregorian calendar remained a constant 584 years.

Same calendar we use? Nice Try, go back to bed and do more reading. You failed!

Comment: Unless Exxon has put in a crude oil distillation top unit to make diesel or fuel "oils", the condensate from the gas is more like propane or butane (in lighters).  Propane cannot be shipped in the pipeline due to it's vapor pressure but light condensates are shipped at a rate of about 40,000/daily from Prudhoe.  The joke of this "new oil" is the fact that these light condensates are not cracked from crude at the refinery, they are distilled out and fetch about $120/barrel.  Ask yourself what about 40 gallons of propane cost you.  The butanes and slightly heavier condensates are worth more money as chemical product feedstocks.  Once again our Elected Mutts have given away a valuable people owned resource.  It's just a fact, the oil companies have more intelligent folks working for them than we Alaskans have working for us.

Comment: Maybe.

Misuse happens.

Several years ago one winter I stopped by our Church to "make a visit".  I do this most days. Drop in and greet Our Lord in the Tabernacle.

That day there was a man on the first pew lying down.  I made my greeting to God and asked Him what could I do.  Seconds later one of our younger priests, a former Naval officer and a good sized man entered.

Together we woke him and tried to sort out his needs.

Long story made shorter.  Our town is a suburb of a larger city and doesn't have a homeless shelter.   One of the other parishioners unbeknownst to us had called to town police.  The cops encouraged us not to take him to a shelter as "these people have all their stuff hidden the woods" and we would be separating him from his stuff.

I volunteered to take him "back to your stuff"

I did, taking him to an intersection one quarter of which are woods and the other quarters are shopping centers.

I gave him a 20 and he made a beeline to the liquor store.

Comment: "Suffering" is a value-judgment you place on a natural process.  It is NATURAL for a lynx to kill and eat snowshoe hares.  The snowshoe hare usually experiences fear and pain right up until the lynx dispatches it.  What you call "suffering."  Is that "bad", or "good"?

How about if you deny the lynx its prey?  It--and if female its offspring--may starve to death.  A slow, lingering, MISERABLE death.  Yet more "suffering".  Is that "bad" or "good"?

Either way this suffering is unavoidable.  Even if you exterminate all the mean ol' lynx to "save da poor widdle bunnies", they'll STILL suffer because they'll overpopulate, die from disease outbreaks, and STARVE.  Let's try  biological fact rather than sentiment.

Pain is a fact of life.  It's one way we know we're alive.  The dead don't feel it.  And the ultimate destination of ALL living things in this world is death.  No getting around it.  You are in most cases KILLING the plants you eat.

We live in the natural world.  Not Disneyland.

Comment: Regarding the WACH caribou in GMU23: Annual harvest by locals has been 14,000 to 16,0000 Caribou, while non-subsistence hunters take less than 3% of the total.
   New regulations stop all harvest of calves and harvest of cows by nonresidents. Subsistence limit is now 5 Caribou/DAY. Non-Subsidence limit is 1 Caribou/YEAR.
  The current estimate of 235,000 (same as it was in 2013) is only 3% less than the 1972 high of 242,000, which is well within the range of normal population fluctuation.
   It seems there is no logical, biological justification for eliminating the non-subsistent harvest of Caribou from the WACH. 
  Eliminating all but subsistence users from harvesting WACH caribou will place an enormous, unnecessary burden on those whose livelihoods depend on fall Caribou hunting, as well as attendant businesses such as hotels, restaurants, and airlines.

Comment: You may also be experiencing "subconscious detachment." I'm currently living with cancer and my husband for a small period of time seemed absent. He was still there to do the necessary things to care for me, but was detached. Subconscious Detachment is your mind trying to protect you from the emotional pain if he were to pass away. It's very common when a loved one has a potentially life ending illness for the mind to slowly pulling away. These things that he's doing that aren't like the pre cancer husband may have always been there but didn't bother you. Now that you're detaching those little things become big and can cause resentment. Once my husband and I became aware of it we were able to work together and we are the happiest we've ever been.
These changes could also be related to his being preoccupied mentally with the fears, etc.. and so his control mechanisms may be less controlled.L

Comment: Cumbrian writes:

"You can lay this issue firmly at the feet of outgoing president Obama with his insistence of his own late nomination."

--

Late nomination?

There's no such thing.

A sitting POTUS can nominate for the SCOTUS  anytime while he is in office.

Obama's nomination of the eminently qualified Merrick Garland was made in march of 2016, which would be 11 months before his term expired.

Historically, nothing unusual about that.

There have been many instances of SCOTUS nominations in the last year of a POTUS term:

March 13, 1912, President William Taft (a Republican) nominated Mahlon Pitney

Woodrow Wilson (a Democrat) made two nominations during 1916.  On January 28, 1916, Wilson nominated Louis Brandeis.

On July 14, 1916, Wilson nominated John Clarke

February 15, 1932, President Herbert Hoover (a Republican) nominated Benjamin Cardozo

On January 4, 1940, President Franklin Roosevelt (a Democrat) nominated Frank Murphy

And more.

Next time, do some research.

Comment: 36 US Code 301:
(a)Designation.—
The composition consisting of the words and music known as the Star-Spangled Banner is the national anthem.
(b)Conduct During Playing.—During a rendition of the national anthem—
(1)when the flag is displayed—
(A) individuals in uniform should give the military salute at the first note of the anthem and maintain that position until the last note;
(B) members of the Armed Forces and veterans who are present but not in uniform may render the military salute in the manner provided for individuals in uniform; and
(C) all other persons present should face the flag and stand at attention with their right hand over the heart, and men not in uniform, if applicable, should remove their headdress with their right hand and hold it at the left shoulder, the hand being over the heart; and
(2) when the flag is not displayed, all present should face toward the music and act in the same manner they would if the flag were displayed.

Comment: And that's part of the problem: the Maritime population is aging as youth move elsewhere seeking better opportunities. Reduced working population means lower tax base. More elderly retirees means more strain on a health care system that's already unsustainable.

I grew up in Nova Scotia, and there were 8 kids in my extended family. Now they're all in their mid-to-late 20s… and all but 1 have left the region. I'm sure 1000s of other families have the same story.

The only possible way to recover, I think, is with a radical Ireland-style makeover: lure business with dramatically lower taxes and less red tape than the rest of the country. Form an economic bloc between the Atlantic provinces: full regulatory harmonization, etc. But this would be almost anathema to the political attitudes of the region (and probably to Canada as a whole). So realistically, it will never happen.

Comment: While this may all be true, 70 people in a study do not provide a meaningful result, ever.  I think you need to have over a 1000 people in a sample group to get anywhere with this sort of thing.  

While there may be all kinds of bizarre 'false facts' circulating on the internet, the media's consistent use of studies like this - with tiny sample populations - to make a point constitutes a more subtle kind of false fact, disclaimer or no disclaimer.  Sometimes we see articles referring to a study where no description of the numbers is provided, but we buy into the idea because the word 'study' triggers a response in us saying it's scientific and so must be true.  

If media wonders why people are questioning some of the content they provide, they need not look too far.

Comment: When I first ran for mayor in 2009, my platform included four main goals.  Reduce crime, restore the financial health of the city, lead the way for energy security amid the Cook Inlet gas shortage and invest in our public infrastructure with our Project 80's renewal plan.

How did we do?  Crime declined every year and our financial strategies were successful, earning Anchorage a AAA bond rating.  State grants and local bonds allowed us to invest over $800 million in our roads, parks trails, and public facilities, the largest investments ever.  Cook Inlet incentives saved the day for energy reliability.  Oh, and let's not forget, turning around the $300 million Port debacle left behind by my predecessor.

AO 37 was controversial but we negotiated virtually all its provisions in our last contracts. The SAP program was/is unfortunate, but we saved taxpayers several times more than the project cost over my two terms. Remember, Had Begich maintained People Soft, SAP would be unnecessary.

Comment: I'm not sure I buy this argument of 'lazy' balance sheets.  A better term would be conservative.  Let's cherry pick a not so conservative balance sheet in Kinder Morgan, rated BBB-.  The stock has been a disaster, declining over 40% in 18 months.  

The true results of all these acquisitions will not be know for 5 to 10 years, and history is not on the Canadian utilities side as higher interest rates, poor deal integration and culture issues, a more challenged regulatory environment and the future difficulty to access to the public market, could cause these deals to be not so rewarding to shareholders.

Comment: Thanks for the link Bill I'm going through it.     No 'system' is going to go on 'auto pilot' and work smoothly for decades.  With social changes and technological changes, health care problems and advances are moving faster that ever.

This concerns me too.  When a pragmatic decision to stay afloat financially has to be made, I have little confidence that a political solution will happen in a timely matter.   Politicians are not health experts,   Health experts tend not to be accountants.   Politicians do what gets them elected, not always the best thing for the nation.

For your link, I think the lesson might be that it's very hard to compare US spending on health care with a more socialized system. if  Either system is not financially balanced.     

I don't think we have any choice but to provide health care as a right, but we'll have to have multiple layers of care.   As an example, generics should be required (when available) to those accepting fed funding.

Comment: For a political narrative to be a political narrative, people have to believe it. So how can political narratives belong to a different category than individual truths? Aren't political narratives just an expression of what we think is common to the political beliefs of many individuals? And how is science a "narrative"? The periodic table is not a narrative. It is a summary of certain laws of physics, which are mathematical expressions summarizing repeatedly observed phenomena.  McNight may be wrong in certain respects but he does not conflate all categories of knowledge with narratives. I have no doubt you are in good faith but post-modern thought allows people to believe what they want to believe without justifying their beliefs, McKnight is right about that.

Comment: The proposed tax changes would result in a tax rate of 73% on investment income of small business owners. The proposed tax changes are unfair and unjust.
